data: Verse inscription recording building of a nymphaeum

Found in May 1771 in excavations undertaken by the Prince of Biscari on
                                the northern side of Piazza Dante and the church of S. Nicolò
I.Sicily with the permission of the Assessorato Regionale dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana - Dipartimento dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana
verse inscription recording building of a nymphaeum
standardisation of template and tidying up encoding
Licensed under a Creative Commons-Attribution 4.0 licence

3rd or possibly early 4rth century CE. Perhaps middle/later
                                    4th century CE
Encoded following the latest EpiDoc guidelines
James Cummings autogenerated EpiDoc output from database
Jonathan Prag made initial revision of the EpiDoc, intial edit of text, added English translation
Jonathan Prag edited the text division and added further metadata
Jonathan Prag added elements for parallel Italian
Simona Stoyanova updated list of languages

Βαιὸν ἐμὲ Νύμφαις ἔργον κάμ
                    
                    
                    οὐ γάρ μοι σθεναρὴν χεῖρ’ ἐπέ
                     
                    αλλ’ ἐν ἐμοὶ καμάτων εὗρεν τέλ
                      
                    ἀγχόθι λαϊνέης αὔλακος ὑδρο
                    
                    τὴν αὐτὸς ποίησεν, ἐς ἠέρα πολλ
                     
                    νᾶμα φέρειν καθαρὸν ἐνναέται
The restorations proposed by Manganaro are adopted here

[---] wrought me, a humble work for the Nymphs.
                    Indeed he did not lay his mighty hand upon me in vain,
                    but in me he found fulfilment of his toils, and gained a statue
                    next the stony water-bearing furrow
                    which he himself made, having lifted it high into the air,
                    to bring a pure stream to those dwelling in Katania.
                    (verses) of Ennoios.

[---] mi ha fatto, un umile lavoro per le Ninfe.
                    Infatti, non mi ha imposto invano la sua potente mano,
                    ma in me ha trovato compimento dei suoi sforzi e ha ottenuto una statua
                    accanto al solco che fornisce l’acqua,
                    che egli stesso ha fatto, avendolo innalzato fino in cielo,
                    per portare un flusso puro a coloro che abitano in Katania.
                    (Versi) di Ennoios.

The name of the individual who carried out the work, and is honoured in the text, is lost at the end
                    of line 1. Traces of the acqueduct which brought water into this part of Catania from the south side
                    of Etna survive. Biscari uncovered remains of a complex which it has been suggested is identical
                    with the nymphaeum (fountain house) mentioned in the later Latin text. The fragmentary mosaic of the
                    months preserved in the museum appears to come from the same location. It is possible that this text
                    commemorates the completion/extension of one branch of the acqueduct, and the construction of a
                    nymphaeum at its terminus. Although Latin was the language of public documents, Greek was used
                    occasionally for highly literary texts of this sort, and the two texts provide another illustration
                    of the bilingualism present in Catania at this time.
ISic000649. Verse inscription recording building of a nymphaeum

7                 ΕΝΝΟΙΟΥ              

Apparatus criticus

  • The restorations proposed by Manganaro are adopted here

English translation

[---] wrought me, a humble work for the Nymphs. Indeed he did not lay his mighty hand upon me in vain, but in me he found fulfilment of his toils, and gained a statue next the stony water-bearing furrow which he himself made, having lifted it high into the air, to bring a pure stream to those dwelling in Katania. (verses) of Ennoios.

Italian translation

[---] mi ha fatto, un umile lavoro per le Ninfe. Infatti, non mi ha imposto invano la sua potente mano, ma in me ha trovato compimento dei suoi sforzi e ha ottenuto una statua accanto al solco che fornisce l’acqua, che egli stesso ha fatto, avendolo innalzato fino in cielo, per portare un flusso puro a coloro che abitano in Katania. (Versi) di Ennoios.

commentary

The name of the individual who carried out the work, and is honoured in the text, is lost at the end of line 1. Traces of the acqueduct which brought water into this part of Catania from the south side of Etna survive. Biscari uncovered remains of a complex which it has been suggested is identical with the nymphaeum (fountain house) mentioned in the later Latin text. The fragmentary mosaic of the months preserved in the museum appears to come from the same location. It is possible that this text commemorates the completion/extension of one branch of the acqueduct, and the construction of a nymphaeum at its terminus. Although Latin was the language of public documents, Greek was used occasionally for highly literary texts of this sort, and the two texts provide another illustration of the bilingualism present in Catania at this time.

[---] wrought me, a humble work for the Nymphs. Indeed he did not lay his mighty hand upon me in vain, but in me he found fulfilment of his toils, and gained a statue next the stony water-bearing furrow which he himself made, having lifted it high into the air, to bring a pure stream to those dwelling in Katania. (verses) of Ennoios.

[---] mi ha fatto, un umile lavoro per le Ninfe. Infatti, non mi ha imposto invano la sua potente mano, ma in me ha trovato compimento dei suoi sforzi e ha ottenuto una statua accanto al solco che fornisce l’acqua, che egli stesso ha fatto, avendolo innalzato fino in cielo, per portare un flusso puro a coloro che abitano in Katania. (Versi) di Ennoios.

Traces of the acqueduct which brought water into this part of Catania from the south side of Etna survive. Biscari uncovered remains of a complex which it has been suggested is identical with the nymphaeum (fountain house) mentioned in the later Latin text. The fragmentary mosaic of the months preserved in the museum appears to come from the same location. It is possible that this text commemorates the completion/extension of one branch of the acqueduct, and the construction of a nymphaeum at its terminus. Although Latin was the language of public documents, Greek was used occasionally for highly literary texts of this sort, and the two texts provide another illustration of the bilingualism present in Catania at this time.
